text: 2. *Diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) work means challenging prevailing norms*. We also have a lot of informal community knowledge and norms that aren't explicitly written down and can have the effect of being intimidating / exclusionary to newcomers. And we can definitely be more proactive about DEI efforts, which means challenging our assumptions of how this community and ecosystem ought to grow and a conscious effort to avoid homophily. Inclusivity means we have to do better than "let it grow organically and they will come", because that is a recipe for attracting only like-minded people who have the same privileged access to the current community network and the bandwidth to work on FOSS as side projects. Written norms like the CoC are one way to codify acceptable behavior as policy to justify moderation interventions.

text: There's a whole related issue about pluralism and cultural misunderstandings also. It's normal in some cultures to question openly, and extremely rude in others. The community is very US/Western Europe and male-heavy, which means a greater propensity to voice one's opinions on both counts. Part of the challenge in multicultural environments is to get others to recognize the differences in norms and avoid crowding out other opinions.

text: One thing I've been thinking about: maybe we should have a community norm that there should be no expectation of unlimited free emotional labor. If you're told that something you're doing is problematic or exclusionary to a group, it's on you to figure it out what the issue is and not expect a full explanation. The reason for this proposed norm is that excluded / discriminated groups constantly have to explain themselves, which places the burden of being included primarily on the excluded groups. It's particularly bad for groups like trans-/nonbinary people where just admitting that you belong to that group opens up liability for criminal prosecution and are disproportionately on the receiving end of  other kinds of risk and violence.
